definitions: having something placed over or on top for protection, concealment, or warmth
having been addressed, discussed, or included in something like insurance or news
examples: The covered bridge protected travelers from bad weather
She kept the food covered to prevent flies
All major topics were covered in the presentation
Your medical expenses are covered by insurance

definitions: not openly shown, engaged in, or avowed; concealed from public knowledge or observation
examples: The agency conducted covert operations behind enemy lines
They exchanged covert glances during the meeting

definitions: strongly wished for or desired, especially something belonging to another person
examples: She won the coveted award for best actress
The coveted position attracted hundreds of applicants

definitions: lacking courage to face danger, difficulty, or pain; showing fear in a shameful way
examples: The cowardly attack targeted innocent civilians
His cowardly behavior disappointed his teammates

definitions: making a pretense of shyness or modesty that is intended to be alluring
reluctant to give details, especially about something regarded as sensitive
examples: She gave him a coy smile across the room
Her coy manner attracted many admirers
The company remained coy about their future plans
He was coy when asked about his salary

definitions: giving a feeling of comfort, warmth, and relaxation in a small space
marked by or providing contentment and ease; suggesting intimacy and informality
examples: The cozy cabin had a fireplace and soft blankets
She curled up in a cozy corner with her book
They had a cozy chat over afternoon tea
The restaurant has a cozy atmosphere perfect for dates

definitions: having lines or splits on the surface but not completely broken apart
showing signs of mental instability or behaving in an eccentric way
examples: The cracked windshield needed immediate replacement
Her lips were cracked from the cold weather
People thought his cracked theories were nonsense
That's a completely cracked idea nobody will support

definitions: behaving in a way that is silly, strange, or not sensible; mentally unsound
examples: You must be crackers to swim in this weather
The whole plan sounds absolutely crackers to me

definitions: extremely good, exciting, or impressive in quality or performance
proceeding at a fast, vigorous pace with energy and efficiency
examples: That was a cracking good movie we watched
She told a cracking story about her travels
We maintained a cracking pace throughout the hike
The team set a cracking speed in the race

definitions: clever at achieving one's aims by indirect or deceitful methods; sly and cunning
examples: The crafty fox outsmarted all the hunters
Her crafty plan helped her avoid detection

definitions: having a rough, uneven surface with many sharp rocks or steep cliffs
examples: His craggy face showed years of outdoor work
The craggy mountains were difficult to climb

definitions: feeling or causing discomfort because of insufficient space for movement or activity
having painful muscle contractions caused by overuse or maintaining one position too long
examples: The cramped airplane seats made the flight uncomfortable
Six people in that cramped apartment was too many
Her cramped fingers struggled to hold the pencil
My legs felt cramped after the long drive

definitions: relating to the skull or cranium; of or involving the head or brain
examples: The cranial nerves control various head functions
Doctors examined the patient's cranial injuries carefully

definitions: ill-tempered, grouchy, or given to complaining; eccentric or strange in behavior
examples: The crank old man yelled at kids constantly
Don't mind his crank theories about aliens

definitions: easily irritated or annoyed; showing bad temper or complaining frequently
examples: The baby gets cranky when she's tired
He's always cranky before his morning coffee

definitions: making or characterized by a loud, breaking sound like things colliding violently
complete and utter in degree; used for emphasis to describe something negative
examples: The crashing waves pounded against the shore
We heard crashing sounds from the kitchen
The party was a crashing bore for everyone
His crashing ignorance of the subject showed immediately

definitions: lacking sensitivity, refinement, or intelligence; showing no understanding of what is proper
examples: His crass comments offended everyone at dinner
The crass commercialization ruined the holiday spirit

definitions: wanted or desired intensely with a powerful, almost uncontrollable longing
examples: The craved chocolate cake tempted her daily
His craved recognition finally came after years

definitions: contemptibly lacking in courage; cowardly in a way that earns scorn
examples: His craven surrender disappointed his loyal supporters
The craven politician refused to defend his principles

definitions: driven insane or acting in a wild, uncontrolled manner from intense emotion
having a network of fine cracks on the surface, like glazed pottery
examples: The crazed gunman was subdued by police
Her crazed laughter frightened the children
The crazed pottery had an interesting antique look
Years of heat left the paint crazed

definitions: having a smooth, soft, rich texture or consistency like cream
having a pale yellow or off-white color resembling cream
examples: The creamy soup warmed us on cold nights
She loved the creamy texture of the cheesecake
The walls were painted in creamy beige tones
She wore a creamy silk dress to the wedding

definitions: able to be believed or trusted; convincing and seeming reasonable or probable
examples: The witness gave credible testimony in court
We need credible evidence to support this claim

definitions: deserving public acknowledgment and praise but not necessarily outstanding; respectable and competent
examples: She did a creditable job organizing the event
The team's creditable performance earned them fourth place

definitions: given recognition or acknowledgment for an achievement, contribution, or quality
examples: She's credited with inventing the new technique
The credited author received all the royalties

definitions: causing an unpleasant feeling of fear or unease; strange in a disturbing way
examples: The creepy old house looked haunted at night
His creepy smile made everyone uncomfortable

definitions: gradually increasing in loudness, force, or intensity until reaching a peak
examples: The crescendo music built to a dramatic climax
Public protests reached a crescendo level last week

definitions: having the curved shape of the moon when less than half illuminated
examples: The crescent moon hung low in the sky
She wore a beautiful crescent shaped pendant

definitions: having a crest, tuft, or ridge on the head or top; adorned with a heraldic device
examples: The crested bird displayed its colorful plumage
Their crested helmets gleamed in the sunlight

definitions: of a rich, deep red color inclining toward purple; the color of blood
examples: The crimson sunset painted the sky beautifully
She wore a stunning crimson dress to the gala

definitions: severely damaged or maimed so as to be unable to function normally
unable to walk or move properly because of disability or injury to legs
examples: The storm left the city's infrastructure crippled
The crippled economy struggled to recover
The accident left him crippled for life
The crippled veteran needed a wheelchair

definitions: causing severe damage, harm, or impairment that prevents normal functioning
examples: The crippling debt forced them to sell their home
She suffered from crippling anxiety before performances

definitions: firm, dry, and easily broken; fresh and pleasant in texture
clear, sharp, and distinct in outline, sound, or manner
examples: The crisp apple crunched when she bit it
I love crisp bacon with my breakfast
The crisp autumn air felt refreshing
She spoke in crisp, clear sentences

definitions: having a firm, dry surface or texture that crunches when bitten or broken
examples: The crispy fried chicken was perfectly cooked
These crispy potato chips are too salty

definitions: bent, twisted, or not straight; having angles or curves where there should be none
dishonest, fraudulent, or engaging in illegal or unethical practices
examples: The crooked tree grew sideways toward the light
His crooked teeth needed years of braces
The crooked politician was finally caught
They exposed the crooked business dealings

definitions: cut short or trimmed; having the ends or edges removed
examples: Her cropped hair suited her face perfectly
The cropped photo focused on just their faces

definitions: marked with or forming a cross shape; having intersecting lines
having gone from one side to another; traversed or passed over
examples: The crossed swords formed the family crest
She wore a crossed pattern on her sweater
The crossed border showed on their passports
Their crossed paths led to a chance meeting

definitions: extending or traveling across a city from one side to another
examples: The crosstown bus takes forty minutes during rush hour
They opened a new crosstown highway

definitions: filled with too many people or things, causing discomfort from lack of space
examples: The crowded subway made her feel claustrophobic
We avoided the crowded beaches during summer

definitions: wearing or adorned with a crown as a symbol of royalty or honor
formally declared as a winner, champion, or holding the highest position
examples: The crowned prince attended the state dinner
A crowned eagle perched on the branch
She was crowned champion after winning three matches
The newly crowned king addressed his subjects

definitions: representing the highest, most important, or final achievement in a series
examples: This novel was her crowning achievement as writer
The crowning moment came when he won gold

definitions: in a natural or raw state; not yet processed or refined
lacking sophistication, subtlety, or completeness; rough and rudimentary
examples: They discovered crude oil beneath the desert
The crude sugar needed further processing
His crude jokes offended the dinner guests
The crude drawing barely resembled a person

definitions: crushed together into creases and wrinkles; rumpled or collapsed in shape
examples: She smoothed out the crumpled paper
His crumpled suit looked like he'd slept in it

definitions: pressed, pounded, or squeezed with force until broken, damaged, or out of shape
utterly disappointed, defeated, or emotionally overwhelmed by bad news or events
examples: The crushed grapes released their juice
Her crushed velvet dress shimmered in light
He felt crushed when she rejected his proposal
The team was crushed by their defeat

definitions: causing overwhelming disappointment, defeat, or physical pressure that destroys
examples: The crushing defeat ended their championship hopes
She felt the crushing weight of responsibility

definitions: of or relating to the group of aquatic animals with hard shells including crabs, lobsters, and shrimp
examples: The restaurant specialized in crustacean dishes
Scientists studied crustacean behavior in tidal pools

definitions: having a hard outer layer or surface, especially from being baked or dried
bad-tempered, irritable, and harsh in manner, especially due to old age
examples: The crusty bread had a soft interior
A crusty layer of snow covered the ground
The crusty old sailor disliked all visitors
Don't mind her crusty remarks, she means well

definitions: producing tears from the eyes, typically from sadness, pain, or strong emotion
demanding immediate action or attention because of being very bad or serious
examples: The crying baby needed to be fed
She was crying tears of joy
There's a crying need for better healthcare
The crying shame is nobody tried to help

definitions: having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure; deliberately enigmatic
examples: His cryptic message left everyone confused
The ancient scroll contained cryptic symbols

definitions: relating to the science or practice of writing or solving codes for secure communication
examples: The cryptographic algorithm protected sensitive data
She studied cryptographic techniques at university

definitions: clear and transparent like crystal; having exceptional clarity
having the structure and form of a crystal with regular atomic arrangement
examples: The crystalline waters revealed colorful fish below
Her crystalline voice rang through the hall
The crystalline structure was visible under the microscope
Scientists examined the crystalline formation
